Description 1: Kursheedt, Gershom and Montefiore, Moses. Philadelphia, PA, This letter is a period copy from Moses Monifiore to Gershom Kursheedt and Solomon Isaacs in New York, thanking the Congregations for donating 64 Pound Sterling to "our poor brethren in the Holy Land". He notes that the Distribution Committee in Amsterdam will handle sending the funds to the needy. On the verso of the letter is a note to the editor, asking that the letter be published. it was then copied and sent to Isaac Leeser for publication in the Occident

On the verso of the letter is a note to the editor, asking that the letter be published. it was then copied and sent to Isaac Leeser for publication in the Occident

It is a fine account of a smaller Southern community's struggle to re-establish Orthodox Judaism after the ravages of the Civil War
Description 2: Letter from Isaac Mayer Wise in Cincinnati to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, in which Wise lauds the success of his newly published Israelite. He also includes a copy of the publication. Letter from L. Carr in Columbia, South Carolina to Rev. Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Description 2: An early Reconstruction era letter from D. Carvalho (1848-1925) in New Orleans to Rev. Isaac Leeser. Carvalho writea a somewhat angry business letter about books

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Carvalho, S. N. Charleston, SC, Letter to Rabbi Isaac Lesser (1806-1868) from the well know communal leader and public figure Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897). In this letter he speaks to an interpretation on Maimonides in an article that was proposed for publication in the Occident. Additionally he opines on other scholarly articles that were sent to Leeser
Description 2: Letter to Rabbi Isaac Lesser (1806-1868) from the well know communal leader and public figure Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897). In this letter he speaks to an interpretation on Maimonides in an article that was proposed for publication in the Occident. Additionally he opines on other scholarly articles that were sent to Leeser

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Carvalho, Solomon Nunes. Charleston, SC, Four page letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho in Charleston, South Carolina to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in which Carvalho discusses the heated public argument that Leeser had with Rev. Solomon Jacobs in Charleston. Carvalho lays out a detailed "tactical" plan by which Leeser should respond to Jacobs without provoking him
Description 2: Four page letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho in Charleston, South Carolina to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in which Carvalho discusses the heated public argument that Leeser had with Rev. Solomon Jacobs in Charleston. Carvalho lays out a detailed "tactical" plan by which Leeser should respond to Jacobs without provoking him

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Carvalho, Solomon Nunes. Charleston, SC, Letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897) in Charleston, South Carolina to Rev. Isaac Leeser (1806-1868) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter Carvalho relays a book order and describes the great pain that he has suffered because of a boil, apologizing for not writing due to his incapacitation
Description 2: Letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897) in Charleston, South Carolina to Rev. Isaac Leeser (1806-1868) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter Carvalho relays a book order and describes the great pain that he has suffered because of a boil, apologizing for not writing due to his incapacitation

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Carvalho, Solomon Nunes. Charleston, SC, Letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897) in Charleston, South Carolina to Rev. Isaac Lesser (1806-1868) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this four page letter, Carvalho tries to sooth Leeser's bruised feelings, after Carvalho intervened in the conflict in Charleston
Description 2: Letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897) in Charleston, South Carolina to Rev. Isaac Lesser (1806-1868) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this four page letter, Carvalho tries to sooth Leeser's bruised feelings, after Carvalho intervened in the conflict in Charleston

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Carvalho, Solomon Nunes. Charleston, SC, Letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897) in Charleston, South Carolina to Rev. Isaac Lesser (1806-1868) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this lengthy three page letter Carvalho details the very public arguments at the Shearit Israel concerning the role of Rev. Ellis Lyons vs. the Reader Dr. E. The Rev. Ellis Lyons wrote a letter excommunicating Dr. E and denounced the Congregation for acting out of order and forfeiting all claims to orthodoxy. Carvalho comments on Lyons' impertinence at excommunicating Dr. E
Description 2: Letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897) in Charleston, South Carolina to Rev. Isaac Lesser (1806-1868) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this lengthy three page letter Carvalho details the very public arguments at the Shearit Israel concerning the role of Rev. Ellis Lyons vs. the Reader Dr. E. The Rev. Ellis Lyons wrote a letter excommunicating Dr. E and denounced the Congregation for acting out of order and forfeiting all claims to orthodoxy. Carvalho comments on Lyons' impertinence at excommunicating Dr. E

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Carvalho, Solomon Nunes. Charleston, SC, Letter from Solomon Nunes Carvalho (1815-1897) in Charleston, South Carolina to Rev. Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Hackenburg, Isaac. Cincinnati, OH, Letter from Isaac Hackenburg in Cincinnati, Ohio to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania with news from Cincinnati. He also asks for some details on the Minor Shohet scandal in Savannah

He also asks for some details on the Minor Shohet scandal in Savannah

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Hart, Isaac. New Orleans, LA, Highly personal letter from Isaac Hart in New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in which Hart responds to a long letter from Leeser, in which Leeser complains of Isaac Wise's Reform activity and competition from other Jewish publications. Hart expresses sympathy that Leeser is not appreciated for all he has done for America's Jews and he suggests changes to Leeser's publication
Description 2: Highly personal letter from Isaac Hart in New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in which Hart responds to a long letter from Leeser, in which Leeser complains of Isaac Wise's Reform activity and competition from other Jewish publications. Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Illowy, Bernard. Philadelphia, PA, Letter from Rabbi Bernard Illowy to Isaac Leeser, asking that Leeser send copies of past Occidents that he requested. He also mentions a Mr. B. Abeles and a Mr. Grunsfelder as persons to see for funds that are owed. Written in German with a translation
Description 2: Letter from Rabbi Bernard Illowy to Isaac Leeser, asking that Leeser send copies of past Occidents that he requested. He also mentions a Mr. B. Abeles and a Mr. Grunsfelder as persons to see for funds that are owed. Written in German with a translation

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Illowy, Henry. New Orleans, LA, Five page letter from Henry Illowy, the son of Rabbi Henry Illowy, in New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. The letter strongly rebukes Leeser for his attacks on his father, and criticizes Leeser for playing the middleground between the Reformers and supporting Rabbis who move toward the Reform
Description 2: Five page letter from Henry Illowy, the son of Rabbi Henry Illowy, in New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. The letter strongly rebukes Leeser for his attacks on his father, and criticizes Leeser for playing the middleground between the Reformers and supporting Rabbis who move toward the Reform

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Isaacs, I. I. New York, NY, Letter from I.I. Isaacs to Isaac Leeser regarding a subscription
Description 2: Letter from I.I. Isaacs to Isaac Leeser regarding a subscription

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Isaacs, J. S. Philadelphia, PA, Note from J.S. Isaacs on the letterhead of "L.J. and I. Phillips and Co., fur and cap manufacturers" in Philadelphia to Isaac Leeser, requesting a bible for his brother
Description 2: Note from J.S. Isaacs on the letterhead of "L.J. and I. Phillips and Co., fur and cap manufacturers" in Philadelphia to Isaac Leeser, requesting a bible for his brother

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Isaacs, Myer Samuel. New York, NY, Letter from Myer S. Isaacs of New York City on the letterhead of "The Jewish Messenger" to Isaac Leeser. The letter acknowledges Leeser's request to call a meeting of the "Board of Delegates."
Description 2: Letter from Myer S. Isaacs of New York City on the letterhead of "The Jewish Messenger" to Isaac Leeser. The letter acknowledges Leeser's request to call a meeting of the "Board of Delegates."

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Jackson, William. Philadelphia, PA, Letter from William Jackson, an inmate in the Philadelphia Country Prison to Isaac Leeser, pleading with Leeser to come and visit him in prison
Description 2: Letter from William Jackson, an inmate in the Philadelphia Country Prison to Isaac Leeser, pleading with Leeser to come and visit him in prison

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Jacobowsky, J. D. Holmesville, OH, Letter from J.D. Jacobowsky in Holmesville, Ohio to Isaac Leeser in which he sends $6.00 for the Occident and $3.00 for one of Leeser's bibles in Hebrew for his friend H. Eichenstine
Description 2: Letter from J.D. Jacobowsky in Holmesville, Ohio to Isaac Leeser in which he sends $6.00 for the Occident and $3.00 for one of Leeser's bibles in Hebrew for his friend H. Eichenstine

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Jacobs, L. Charleston, SC, Signed letter fragment from L. Jacobs in Charleston, SC to Isaac Leeser, containing a diatribe against Jacobs's antagonist
Description 2: Signed letter fragment from L. Jacobs in Charleston, SC to Isaac Leeser, containing a diatribe against Jacobs's antagonist

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Jarodawski, L. Pittsburgh, PA, Letter from Mr. L. Jarodawski in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to Issac Leeser in Philadelphia, relating that Mr. Lecy of Philadelphia is dying. Jarodawski, on behalf of his community, asks Leeser to mediate with his brother, Mr. Tobias, as the cost has put a burden on the small community
Description 2: Letter from Mr. L. Jarodawski in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to Issac Leeser in Philadelphia, relating that Mr. Lecy of Philadelphia is dying. Jarodawski, on behalf of his community, asks Leeser to mediate with his brother, Mr. Tobias, as the cost has put a burden on the small community

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and John S. Meehan. Washington, DC, A printed form with the autograph of John S. Meehan, the librarian of the Library of Congress, acknowledging the receipt of "The book of daily prayers for every day in the year according to the custom of the German and Polish Jews." Edited by Isaac Leeser and printed by Sherman, 1848
Description 2: A printed form with the autograph of John S. Meehan, the librarian of the Library of Congress, acknowledging the receipt of "The book of daily prayers for every day in the year according to the custom of the German and Polish Jews." Edited by Isaac Leeser and printed by Sherman, 1848

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Jonas, Joseph. Cinncinati, OH, Two letters written to Isaac Leeser on one sheet. The first page is written by Lewis Abraham, from Cincinnati, Ohio. The last two pages are from Joseph Jonas, a watchmaker and silversmith by trade, who was one of the first Jews to settle in the area west of the Allegheny Mountains
Description 2: Two letters written to Isaac Leeser on one sheet. The first page is written by Lewis Abraham, from Cincinnati, Ohio. The last two pages are from Joseph Jonas, a watchmaker and silversmith by trade, who was one of the first Jews to settle in the area west of the Allegheny Mountains

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Jones, Alfred T. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Alfred T. Jones, Secretary of the Hebrew Education Society of Philadelphia. The letter contains the annual report of the society, listing the officers and Board of Directors, and the treasurer's report. This document was sent to Isaac leeser for publication in The Occident
Description 2: A letter from Alfred T. Jones, Secretary of the Hebrew Education Society of Philadelphia. The letter contains the annual report of the society, listing the officers and Board of Directors, and the treasurer's report. This document was sent to Isaac leeser for publication in The Occident

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Jones, Israel J. Mobile, AL, A letter from Israel Jones in Mobile, Alabama to Isaac Leeser, informing him of a fire that destroyed the Sha'arai Shomayim Synagogue in Mobile, Alabama, of which Jones is the president, and asking that a plea for donations be placed in the Occident
Description 2: A letter from Israel Jones in Mobile, Alabama to Isaac Leeser, informing him of a fire that destroyed the Sha'arai Shomayim Synagogue in Mobile, Alabama, of which Jones is the president, and asking that a plea for donations be placed in the Occident

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Joseph, Jacob Henry. Montreal, Canada, A letter written by Jacob Henry Joseph from Montreal, Canada to Rev. Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Joseph is a successful Canadian financier, active in the Jewish Community and an associate of Leeserâs. In this letter, Mr. Joseph takes Leeser to task for his difficult personality and unwillingness to satisfy anyone
Description 2: A letter written by Jacob Henry Joseph from Montreal, Canada to Rev. Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Joseph is a successful Canadian financier, active in the Jewish Community and an associate of Leesers. In this letter, Mr. Joseph takes Leeser to task for his difficult personality and unwillingness to satisfy anyone

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Joseph, Jesse. Montreal, Canada, A three page letter from a Canadian communal leader, Jesse Joseph of Montreal, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The first part of the letter contains detailed suggestions as to how he might help Leeser sell books and his newspaper in Canada. He then talks about the state of the Canadian economy. Lastly he deals with his review of the Jewish institutions
Description 2: A three page letter from a Canadian communal leader, Jesse Joseph of Montreal, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The first part of the letter contains detailed suggestions as to how he might help Leeser sell books and his newspaper in Canada. He then talks about the state of the Canadian economy. Lastly he deals with his review of the Jewish institutions

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Joseph, Jesse. Montreal, Canada, A two page letter from a Canadian communal leader, Jesse Joseph of Montreal, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter deals with financial matters but importantly takes Leeser to task for ignoring Jewish happenings in Canada, particularly the work that was submitted to him by Dr. David
Description 2: A two page letter from a Canadian communal leader, Jesse Joseph of Montreal, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter deals with financial matters but importantly takes Leeser to task for ignoring Jewish happenings in Canada, particularly the work that was submitted to him by Dr. David

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Joseph, Jesse. Montreal, Canada, A two page letter from a Canadian communal leader, Jesse Joseph of Montreal, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. This is a chatty letter full of personal detail and insights into unrecorded family history
Description 2: A two page letter from a Canadian communal leader, Jesse Joseph of Montreal, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. This is a chatty letter full of personal detail and insights into unrecorded family history

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Baltimore, MD, A letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania regarding travel arrangements and family matters
Description 2: A letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania regarding travel arrangements and family matters

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Baltimore, MD, A letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Judah cautions Leeser to be more tolerant in his criticism of others. He also includes some local news
Description 2: A letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Judah cautions Leeser to be more tolerant in his criticism of others. He also includes some local news

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Baltimore, MD, A letter from David Judah in Baltimore, Maryland to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in which Judah writes urgently about Zalma Rehine's poor health and suggests Isaac comes to visit his Uncle
Description 2: A letter from David Judah in Baltimore, Maryland to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in which Judah writes urgently about Zalma Rehine's poor health and suggests Isaac comes to visit his Uncle

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Baltimore, MD, A letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania regarding family matters
Description 2: A letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania regarding family matters

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Baltimore, MD, A letter from David Judah to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania regarding the death of Ms. Aguilar, a noted Jewish authoress
Description 2: A letter from David Judah to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania regarding the death of Ms. Aguilar, a noted Jewish authoress

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Baltimore, MD, A letter from David Judah to Isaac Leeser regarding book business
Description 2: A letter from David Judah to Isaac Leeser regarding book business

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Baltimore, MD, A letter written by David Judah from Richmond, Virginia to a young Isaac Leeser in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Judah expresses his reservations and gives suggestions on the draft of Leeser's first book "Instructions in the Mosaic Religion"
Description 2: A letter written by David Judah from Richmond, Virginia to a young Isaac Leeser in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Judah expresses his reservations and gives suggestions on the draft of Leeser's first book "Instructions in the Mosaic Religion"

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Baltimore, MD, A one page letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Judah suggests that Leeser, who had just taken his position at Mikveh Israel, stop publishing in what Judah calls the "Christian form."
Description 2: A one page letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Judah suggests that Leeser, who had just taken his position at Mikveh Israel, stop publishing in what Judah calls the "Christian form."

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Philadelphia, PA, A two page letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia to David Judah of Baltimore, Maryland, in which he expresses his unhappiness with his Philadelphian congregants. The letter also speeks to Leeser's banking and financial issues
Description 2: A two page letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia to David Judah of Baltimore, Maryland, in which he expresses his unhappiness with his Philadelphian congregants. The letter also speeks to Leeser's banking and financial issues

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, David. Richmond, VA, A two page letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to a young Isaac Leeser in Baltimore, Maryland. In this chatty letter, Judah discusses commission activity for Mrs. Jacobs, a Sunday trip on the James River, his trip to Norfolk where he had breakfast with Solomon Marks, and his stage coach ride to Philadelphia
Description 2: A two page letter from David Judah in Richmond, Virginia to a young Isaac Leeser in Baltimore, Maryland. In this chatty letter, Judah discusses commission activity for Mrs. Jacobs, a Sunday trip on the James River, his trip to Norfolk where he had breakfast with Solomon Marks, and his stage coach ride to Philadelphia

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, Reinah. Baltimore, MD, Letter requesting assistance with rent
Description 2: Letter requesting assistance with rent

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, Rumah. Charleston, SC, A letter from Rumah Judah, Isaac Leeser's aunt and wife of Zalma Rehine, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Writing during her trip to see relatives in Charleston, South Carolina, Rumah relates her family observations
Description 2: A letter from Rumah Judah, Isaac Leeser's aunt and wife of Zalma Rehine, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Writing during her trip to see relatives in Charleston, South Carolina, Rumah relates her family observations

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Judah, Samuel. Vincennes, IL, A letter from Samuel Judah in Vincennes, Indiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, he discusses reading a book from London on the Karaites and is anxious to know if Leeser has any publications on the subject in Philadelphia. He also orders a book and discusses its binding
Description 2: A letter from Samuel Judah in Vincennes, Indiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, he discusses reading a book from London on the Karaites and is anxious to know if Leeser has any publications on the subject in Philadelphia. He also orders a book and discusses its binding

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Katz, Benjamin. Dulman, Germany, A one page letter from Rabbi Benjamin Jacob Katz, a former teacher of Leeser's, from Dulman, Germany to Isaac Leeser in Muster, Germany. The letter is written almost entirely in Yiddish, and is the only known document that survives from Leeser's formative period in Europe
Description 2: A one page letter from Rabbi Benjamin Jacob Katz, a former teacher of Leeser's, from Dulman, Germany to Isaac Leeser in Muster, Germany. The letter is written almost entirely in Yiddish, and is the only known document that survives from Leeser's formative period in Europe

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Kohn, A. Chicago, IL, A three page letter written by A. Kohn of Chicago, Illinois to Isaac Leeserin New York City. In this letter, Kohn expresses his concern for Judaism in America and the need for Jewish institutions such as hospitals, colleges and sabbath schools. A. Kohn will go on to found the first synagogue in Chicago, "Kehilath Anshe Ma'ativ " in 1851
Description 2: A three page letter written by A. Kohn of Chicago, Illinois to Isaac Leeserin New York City. In this letter, Kohn expresses his concern for Judaism in America and the need for Jewish institutions such as hospitals, colleges and sabbath schools. A. Kohn will go on to found the first synagogue in Chicago, "Kehilath Anshe Ma'ativ " in 1851

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Kursheedt, Gershom. New Orleans, LA, A four page letter written by Gershom Kursheedt in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In the letter, Kursheedt outlines his secretive plans to have Judah Touro's remains brought back to Newport, Rhode Island for burial. This letter goes into great detail regarding the funeral, including the required length and style of the speakers as well as the prohibition of a public procession in New York City. It also speaks to funds that should go to Leeser's proposed Educational Society ($20,000) but will not be forth coming unless Leeser takes legal action
Description 2: A four page letter written by Gershom Kursheedt in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In the letter, Kursheedt outlines his secretive plans to have Judah Touro's remains brought back to Newport, Rhode Island for burial. This letter goes into great detail regarding the funeral, including the required length and style of the speakers as well as the prohibition of a public procession in New York City. It also speaks to funds that should go to Leeser's proposed Educational Society ($20,000) but will not be forth coming unless Leeser takes legal action

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Kursheedt, Gershom. New Orleans, LA, A four page letter written by Gershom Kursheedt in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. The first part of the letter is a unique insight as to how Kursheedt "handles" Judah Touro when asking for funds and Touro's expected reaction. The second is a surprising discussion on the Jews in China. The remainder is Kursheedt's concern as to his personal lack of funds to further help Jews and then his observations on the local scene with the Reform
Description 2: A four page letter written by Gershom Kursheedt in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. The first part of the letter is a unique insight as to how Kursheedt "handles" Judah Touro when asking for funds and Touro's expected reaction. The second is a surprising discussion on the Jews in China. The remainder is Kursheedt's concern as to his personal lack of funds to further help Jews and then his observations on the local scene with the Reform

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Kursheedt, Gershom. New Orleans, LA, A three page letter written by Gershom Kursheedt in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, Kursheedt chides Leeser for attacking his friends, and writes his point by point objections to Dr. Wise's Reform elements
Description 2: A three page letter written by Gershom Kursheedt in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, Kursheedt chides Leeser for attacking his friends, and writes his point by point objections to Dr. Wise's Reform elements

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Kursheedt, M. New Orleans, LA, A one page letter from Rabbi M. Kursheedt in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser, submitting the list of newly elected officers and trustees of Sharmari Hafsed. In a separate letter on the same page he notes that Leeser had recommend Rev. H. A. Henry, but they have recently learned that he had taken a position in Cincinnati
Description 2: A one page letter from Rabbi M. Kursheedt in New Orleans to Isaac Leeser, submitting the list of newly elected officers and trustees of Sharmari Hafsed. In a separate letter on the same page he notes that Leeser had recommend Rev. H. A. Henry, but they have recently learned that he had taken a position in Cincinnati

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Kuttnauer, S. Baltimore, MD, A letter from S. Kuttnauer of Baltimore, Maryland to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia.The letter is written entirely in German with few Hebrew words interspersed. Kuttnauer writes that a friend in Washington D.C. suggested that he write and that he just came from Frankfurt, Germany. He asks Leeser to help him find a suitable job
Description 2: A letter from S. Kuttnauer of Baltimore, Maryland to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia.The letter is written entirely in German with few Hebrew words interspersed. Kuttnauer writes that a friend in Washington D.C. suggested that he write and that he just came from Frankfurt, Germany. He asks Leeser to help him find a suitable job

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Labatt, Abraham Cohen. San Francisco, CA, A letter from Abraham Cohen Labatt, a prominent pioneer of Reform Judaism, in San Francisco to Isaac Leeser. Labatt writes about how well his congregation is doing and asks Leeser to him him find a suitable Rabbi
Description 2: A letter from Abraham Cohen Labatt, a prominent pioneer of Reform Judaism, in San Francisco to Isaac Leeser. Labatt writes about how well his congregation is doing and asks Leeser to him him find a suitable Rabbi

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Labatt, D. C. New Orleans, LA, A letter from David Cohen Labatt in New orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser, in which Labatt notes that he cannot find a representative to sell Occidents in New Orleans
Description 2: A letter from David Cohen Labatt in New orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser, in which Labatt notes that he cannot find a representative to sell Occidents in New Orleans

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Labatt, H. New Orleans, LA, A letter from H. Labatt of New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Labatt writes of his concerns of anti-Semitic slurs against two Louisiana elected officials, J.P. Benjamin, a Whig senator elect, and E.W. Moise, a Democrat ex-speaker of the house
Description 2: A letter from H. Labatt of New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Labatt writes of his concerns of anti-Semitic slurs against two Louisiana elected officials, J.P. Benjamin, a Whig senator elect, and E.W. Moise, a Democrat ex-speaker of the house

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Labatt, Henry Jacob. New Orleans, LA, A letter from Henry Jacob Labatt (1832-1900) of New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia regarding book business. It includes a book rquest from Judah Touro
Description 2: A letter from Henry Jacob Labatt (1832-1900) of New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia regarding book business. It includes a book rquest from Judah Touro

Description 2: A letter from Henry Jacob Labatt (1832-1900) of New Orleans, Louisiana to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Lanfirtz, J. Fort Wayne, IN, A letter from J. Lanfirtz in Fort Wayne, Indiana to Isaac Leeser. His letter is solely about the Reform Movement
Description 2: A letter from J. Lanfirtz in Fort Wayne, Indiana to Isaac Leeser. His letter is solely about the Reform Movement

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Lavsano, Joshua. Charleston, SC, A letter from Joshua Lavsano in Charleston, South Carolina to Isaac Leeser. He writes of the major problems the Jewish Community is having regarding the battle over the form of services in the synagogue Beth Elohim. He relates that as a member, he can see no possibility of cooperation. He thanks Reverend Leeser for his intervention but things have gone down divergant paths. He notes that a meeting was held to consider the Philadelphia recommendation of one joint synagogue, but it was soundly rebuffed
Description 2: A letter from Joshua Lavsano in Charleston, South Carolina to Isaac Leeser. He writes of the major problems the Jewish Community is having regarding the battle over the form of services in the synagogue Beth Elohim. He relates that as a member, he can see no possibility of cooperation. He thanks Reverend Leeser for his intervention but things have gone down divergant paths. He notes that a meeting was held to consider the Philadelphia recommendation of one joint synagogue, but it was soundly rebuffed

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Lazarus, Joshua. Charleston, SC, A letter from Joshua Lazarus of Charleston, South Carolina, president and founder of the Charleston Gas Light Co. and president of the Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim Synagogue, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. He describes in detail how he wants his bible bound
Description 2: A letter from Joshua Lazarus of Charleston, South Carolina, president and founder of the Charleston Gas Light Co. and president of the Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim Synagogue, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. He describes in detail how he wants his bible bound

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Leeser, Abraham. Muenster, Germany, This single sheet letter is from Isaac Leeser's uncle, Abraham Leeser on one side and Isaac Leeser's sister, Leah Lippmann on the other. The two are writing to Isaac Leeser to request that he allow them to accompy him on his trip to America (though neither of them actually did in the end). It is from Sternberg, Germany, 1823 and is addressed to Isaac Leeser, who was then in Munster Germany where he had just received his final formal education. The letter is entirely penned in Yiddish, and accompanied with a reliable translation to English accomplished circa 1950
Description 2: This single sheet letter is from Isaac Leeser's uncle, Abraham Leeser on one side and Isaac Leeser's sister, Leah Lippmann on the other. The two are writing to Isaac Leeser to request that he allow them to accompy him on his trip to America (though neither of them actually did in the end). It is from Sternberg, Germany, 1823 and is addressed to Isaac Leeser, who was then in Munster Germany where he had just received his final formal education. The letter is entirely penned in Yiddish, and accompanied with a reliable translation to English accomplished circa 1950

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Leeser, Jacob Lippman. Baltimore, MD, A letter from jacob Lippman Leeser in Baltimore, Maryland to his older brother Isaac Leeser. Jacob writes of family and friends and sends his regards to Miss Cozen, Isaac's gentile house keeper. Letters from Jacob Leeser are rare, as much of Leeser's personal family correspondence was destroyed at his death
Description 2: A letter from jacob Lippman Leeser in Baltimore, Maryland to his older brother Isaac Leeser. Jacob writes of family and friends and sends his regards to Miss Cozen, Isaac's gentile house keeper. Letters from Jacob Leeser are rare, as much of Leeser's personal family correspondence was destroyed at his death

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Leevier, R. D. New York, NY, A three page letter from R.D. Leevier in New York City to isaac Leeser. He had been referred by a Mr. Sternberger to Leeser and is writing to him for a second time âforwarding an introduction from Mr. Jonas of Jamaica", with hopes of visiting Philadelphia
Description 2: A three page letter from R.D. Leevier in New York City to isaac Leeser. He had been referred by a Mr. Sternberger to Leeser and is writing to him for a second time forwarding an introduction from Mr. Jonas of Jamaica", with hopes of visiting Philadelphia

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Leo, Simeon N. New York, NY, A signed letter from Simeon N. Leo to Isaac leeser, sending a ticket to their fund raiser at Niblos Saloon for an association to raise funds to erect an asylum for the aged and infirmed of the Jewish persuasion. Description 2: A signed letter from Simeon N. Leo to Isaac leeser, sending a ticket to their fund raiser at Niblos Saloon for an association to raise funds to erect an asylum for the aged and infirmed of the Jewish persuasion. He also requests a free ad in the Occident

Description 2: A letter written by Theodore Leon of New Orleans to Isaac Leeser Esq, Editor of the Occident. He asks that Leeser discontinue sending the Occident to Edward Leon, since he has moved to Europe

In this letter, Leopold submits a letter donation to Jerusalem and wishes Leeser well on bringing up the educational standards of Jewish youth. Additionally, he sends funds to extend his subscription to the Occident

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Levi, Solomon L. Clear Spring, MD, A letter from Solomon L. Levi to Isaac Leeser, sending money for a one year subscription to the Occident and a bound copy of the Enlgish Bible
Description 2: A letter from Solomon L. Levi to Isaac Leeser, sending money for a one year subscription to the Occident and a bound copy of the Enlgish Bible

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Levin, S. Syracuse, NY, A letter from S. Levin to Isaac Leeser, containing a progress report of the the Cheneseth Shalom synagogue in Syracuse, New York, which Leeser had consecrated a month prior. The letter relates in detail that things are going well
Description 2: A letter from S. Levin to Isaac Leeser, containing a progress report of the the Cheneseth Shalom synagogue in Syracuse, New York, which Leeser had consecrated a month prior. The letter relates in detail that things are going well

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Levingston, Levi H. Bethania, NC, A letter from Levi H. Levingston in Bethania, North Carolina to Isaac Leeser. The letter is a fine example of an educated lay person from the rural hinterlands of America turning to Leeser with questions in depth on certain Biblical passages and interpretations. He also thanks Leeser for the books that he had ordered

Description 2: Signed letter from H. Levinson from the firm of Harmam and Levinson in Texas to Isaac Leeser, ordering Occidents

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Levy, Esther. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Esther Levy, Matron of the Jewish Foster Home in Philadelphia, to Isaac Leeser, asking for the loan of a prayer book for the high holidays

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Nathan, Moses N. New Orleans, LA, A four page letter written by Rev. Moses N. Nathan from New Orleans, Louisiana to Rev. Isaac Lesser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It is an historically important account of the difficulties mid-19th century Orthox Rabbi's were having in the American Congregations that were in a state of flux between traditional and reform thought. He tells Lesser that he is leaving his position at "The Dispersed of Judah"
Description 2: A four page letter written by Rev. Moses N. Nathan from New Orleans, Louisiana to Rev. Isaac Lesser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It is an historically important account of the difficulties mid-19th century Orthox Rabbi's were having in the American Congregations that were in a state of flux between traditional and reform thought. He tells Lesser that he is leaving his position at "The Dispersed of Judah"

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Nathan, Moses N. New Orleans, LA, A handwritten sermon by Moses N. Nathan, written only days after he had joined his new congregation in New Orleans, sent to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Called upon to dedicate their new building, the sermon seeks Gods blessings on the consecration of the new synagogue and its members
Description 2: A handwritten sermon by Moses N. Nathan, written only days after he had joined his new congregation in New Orleans, sent to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. Called upon to dedicate their new building, the sermon seeks Gods blessings on the consecration of the new synagogue and its members

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Nathan, Moses N. New Orleans, LA, A three page letter, written by Rabbi Moses N. Nathan and Gershom Kursheedt to Isaac Leeser. In this letter they have forwarded for K.K. Beni Israel's contract with Rabbi Nathan. Then, Rabbi Nathan expresses the "city's " indignation at the treatment of Leeser by Mikveh Israel and he gives him advice. Lastly, Kursheedt, while verifying that the contract is correct, expresses his views of Leeser's departure from Mikveh Israel
Description 2: A three page letter, written by Rabbi Moses N. Nathan and Gershom Kursheedt to Isaac Leeser. In this letter they have forwarded for K.K. Beni Israel's contract with Rabbi Nathan. Then, Rabbi Nathan expresses the "city's " indignation at the treatment of Leeser by Mikveh Israel and he gives him advice. Lastly, Kursheedt, while verifying that the contract is correct, expresses his views of Leeser's departure from Mikveh Israel

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Nathan, Moses N. St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, A highly detailed six page letter written by Rev. Moses N. Nathan from St. Thomas, Virgin Islands to Rev. Isaac Lesser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter deals with three themes. The first is that his wife is an invalid and he is working day and night to make certain she is cared for when he is gone. The second is an important Rabbinic debate with Leeser on trainng for a young man before Bar Mitzvah. The last deals with the difficulties of trying to compromise with the Reform ideas on the Island
Description 2: A highly detailed six page letter written by Rev. Moses N. Nathan from St. Thomas, Virgin Islands to Rev. Isaac Lesser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter deals with three themes. The first is that his wife is an invalid and he is working day and night to make certain she is cared for when he is gone. The second is an important Rabbinic debate with Leeser on trainng for a young man before Bar Mitzvah. The last deals with the difficulties of trying to compromise with the Reform ideas on the Island

Description 2: A letter written by Rev. Moses N. Nathan from St. Thomas, Virgin Islands to Rev. Isaac Lesser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Isaac. Baltimore, MD, A three page letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle Zalma Rehine in Baltimore, Maryland. In this detailed letter, Leeser writes to his uncle about family and friends, as well as about the effects of the financial Panic of 1837 on the economy, and Jewish businessmen in particular
Description 2: A three page letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle Zalma Rehine in Baltimore, Maryland. In this detailed letter, Leeser writes to his uncle about family and friends, as well as about the effects of the financial Panic of 1837 on the economy, and Jewish businessmen in particular

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Isaac. Warrenton, VA, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Warrenton, Virginia to his nephew, Isaac Leeser. He writes that he is vacationing with his wife, who is not well, near Barkley Springs, and describes his accomodations
Description 2: A letter from Zalma Rehine in Warrenton, Virginia to his nephew, Isaac Leeser. He writes that he is vacationing with his wife, who is not well, near Barkley Springs, and describes his accomodations

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to both his nephews, Isaac and Jacob Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine addresses Jacob in the third person, and encourages him to learn English.He goes on to encourage his good behavior so that he will do well in business and speaks of contacts that might be made for young Jacob Leeser
Description 2: A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to both his nephews, Isaac and Jacob Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine addresses Jacob in the third person, and encourages him to learn English.He goes on to encourage his good behavior so that he will do well in business and speaks of contacts that might be made for young Jacob Leeser

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. The letter discusses family news and the controversy caused by Mrs. Cohen, a member of a prominent Baltimore Jewish family, being inclined to the Christian church
Description 2: A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. The letter discusses family news and the controversy caused by Mrs. Cohen, a member of a prominent Baltimore Jewish family, being inclined to the Christian church

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. This chatty letter contains the well-wishes of Leeser's relatives and friends, a Mr. and Mrs, N.T. Cohen
Description 2: A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. This chatty letter contains the well-wishes of Leeser's relatives and friends, a Mr. and Mrs, N.T. Cohen

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine describes his sadness at the loss of his brother in law, Barry Judah, and the pitiable mental state of his sister, Reinah Judah
Description 2: A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine describes his sadness at the loss of his brother in law, Barry Judah, and the pitiable mental state of his sister, Reinah Judah

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine teases Leeser about his neglectful letter writing, and praises him for officiating at a recent wedding. He also sends the well wishes of friends in Baltimore to the notable Philadelphian Peixotto family. The letter has Rehine's full signature and is entirely in his hand
Description 2: A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine teases Leeser about his neglectful letter writing, and praises him for officiating at a recent wedding. He also sends the well wishes of friends in Baltimore to the notable Philadelphian Peixotto family. The letter has Rehine's full signature and is entirely in his hand

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine wirtes about an Etting weddomg that Leeser did not officiate, and notes that Philip Cohen of Baltimore, the son of Israel I. Cohen, was pleased with one of Leeser's discourses
Description 2: A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. In this letter, Rehine wirtes about an Etting weddomg that Leeser did not officiate, and notes that Philip Cohen of Baltimore, the son of Israel I. Cohen, was pleased with one of Leeser's discourses

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. The letter is replete with well-wishes to Leeser from his friends and relatives. Zalma also asks that Leeser take care of himself and expresses his wish for the continued health of Isaac and his brother Jacob
Description 2: A letter from Zalma Rehine in Baltimore to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, in Philadelphia. The letter is replete with well-wishes to Leeser from his friends and relatives. Zalma also asks that Leeser take care of himself and expresses his wish for the continued health of Isaac and his brother Jacob

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, A signed note from Zalma Rehine to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, regarding business
Description 2: A signed note from Zalma Rehine to his nephew, Isaac Leeser, regarding business

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Baltimore, MD, This one page letter to Isaac Leeser is from two writers in Baltimore. The first is from David Judah, noting that he is closing the castor oil business and asks Isaac to tell Solomon Levy to close out the oil in his hands at $1 or better. The second part is a note from Leeser's uncle, Zalma Rehine, mostly about bad business dealings with Mr. Jacobs. This is an unusually detailed business letter of Jewish commercial problems in the early part of the 19th Century
Description 2: This one page letter to Isaac Leeser is from two writers in Baltimore. The first is from David Judah, noting that he is closing the castor oil business and asks Isaac to tell Solomon Levy to close out the oil in his hands at $1 or better. The second part is a note from Leeser's uncle, Zalma Rehine, mostly about bad business dealings with Mr. Jacobs. This is an unusually detailed business letter of Jewish commercial problems in the early part of the 19th Century

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his anxiety at waiting to see if he has a posting with Mikveh Israel
Description 2: A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his anxiety at waiting to see if he has a posting with Mikveh Israel

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his concerns that the Jews are being blamed for the financial Panic of 1837. Leeser goes on to discuss failures in New Orleans, and to send thanks to Philip Cohen of Baltimore for his literary support
Description 2: A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his concerns that the Jews are being blamed for the financial Panic of 1837. Leeser goes on to discuss failures in New Orleans, and to send thanks to Philip Cohen of Baltimore for his literary support

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his duties as Hazan at Mikveh Israel in vivid detail
Description 2: A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser describes his duties as Hazan at Mikveh Israel in vivid detail

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser outlines his contractual difficulties with the congregation of Mikveh Israel over a new three year contract
Description 2: A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser outlines his contractual difficulties with the congregation of Mikveh Israel over a new three year contract

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Rehine, Zalma. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser provides a detailed description of his campaigning for the minister's job at Mikveh Israel, after seven years as Hazan. It outlines the position of various key members and his strategy relative to them
Description 2: A letter from Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to his uncle, Zalma Rehine, in Baltimore, Maryland. In this letter, Leeser provides a detailed description of his campaigning for the minister's job at Mikveh Israel, after seven years as Hazan. It outlines the position of various key members and his strategy relative to them

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Reinah, Judah. Baltimore, MD, A highly personal and well written letter from Reinah (Judah?) in Baltimore to Isaac Leeser. In it she complains of having few customers and little money, and asks Lesser for some financial help
Description 2: A highly personal and well written letter from Reinah (Judah?) in Baltimore to Isaac Leeser. In it she complains of having few customers and little money, and asks Lesser for some financial help

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Ridskopf, J. New York, NY, A printed broadside for Dr. J. Ridskopf's select male and female academy or classical English and commercial institute. On the reverse is a letter to Isaac Leeser, requesting a notice in the paper and asking for ad prices
Description 2: A printed broadside for Dr. J. Ridskopf's select male and female academy or classical English and commercial institute. On the reverse is a letter to Isaac Leeser, requesting a notice in the paper and asking for ad prices

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Ritterband, L. M. New York, NY, A letter from Mrs. L. M. Ritterband in New York City to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, Mrs. Ritterband relates the plight of her son, a skilled stone carver with a wife and six children. She asks Leeser to visit his shop when he is next in New York, and is clearly hoping that Leeser will mention his skills in the Occident
Description 2: A letter from Mrs. L. M. Ritterband in New York City to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, Mrs. Ritterband relates the plight of her son, a skilled stone carver with a wife and six children. She asks Leeser to visit his shop when he is next in New York, and is clearly hoping that Leeser will mention his skills in the Occident

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Roget, A. Baltimore, MD, A letter from A. Roget to Isaac Leeser regarding a subscription
Description 2: A letter from A. Roget to Isaac Leeser regarding a subscription

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Runkel, Philip. New Orleans, LA, A letter from Phillip Runkel, representing a Spanish-Portuguese synagogue in New Orleans, to Isaac Leeser. He writes that he is visitig New York City and would like to interview hazans while there. The letter is written on the letterhead of Robbins, Calhoun and Co., New York City
Description 2: A letter from Phillip Runkel, representing a Spanish-Portuguese synagogue in New Orleans, to Isaac Leeser. He writes that he is visitig New York City and would like to interview hazans while there. The letter is written on the letterhead of Robbins, Calhoun and Co., New York City

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Salomon, D. Mobile, AL, A letter from D. Salomon of Mobile, Alabama to Isaac Leeser. In this letter, he details the consecration of Shaari Shomayin in Mobile. The letter also deals with Leeser's request for funds for his proposed Jewish Publication Society, Leeser's edition of the Pentateuch, and Salomon's request for Leeser to hold space in the Occident for his "short sermons."
Description 2: A letter from D. Salomon of Mobile, Alabama to Isaac Leeser. In this letter, he details the consecration of Shaari Shomayin in Mobile. The letter also deals with Leeser's request for funds for his proposed Jewish Publication Society, Leeser's edition of the Pentateuch, and Salomon's request for Leeser to hold space in the Occident for his "short sermons."

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Sampson, Emanuel. Philadelphia, PA, A letter from Emanuel Sampson to Rev. Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, he asks that an act of kindness he received from Joseph Andrews, who offered a burial plot in Memphis, Tennessee to Sampson's child at no cost, be reported in the Occident
Description 2: A letter from Emanuel Sampson to Rev. Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. In this letter, he asks that an act of kindness he received from Joseph Andrews, who offered a burial plot in Memphis, Tennessee to Sampson's child at no cost, be reported in the Occident

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Samuel, B. M. Evergreen, AL, A letter from B.M. Samuel, the sole Jew in Evergreen, Alabama, to Isaac Leeser, asking for prayer books for himself and for a few other Jews in Claiborne, Alabama
Description 2: A letter from B.M. Samuel, the sole Jew in Evergreen, Alabama, to Isaac Leeser, asking for prayer books for himself and for a few other Jews in Claiborne, Alabama

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Samuel, Frederick. Philadelphia, PA, A resolution written by Isaac Leeser, allowing the burial of Frederick Samuel to be buried at Mikveh Israel, despite the fact that he was not a member of Mikveh Israel
Description 2: A resolution written by Isaac Leeser, allowing the burial of Frederick Samuel to be buried at Mikveh Israel, despite the fact that he was not a member of Mikveh Israel

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Samuel. Wilkes Barre, PA, Letter from Samuel in Wilkesbarre, PA to Isaac Leeser, expressing his wish to see a favorable article about American Jews in the Christian press reprinted by Leeser
Description 2: Letter from Samuel in Wilkesbarre, PA to Isaac Leeser, expressing his wish to see a favorable article about American Jews in the Christian press reprinted by Leeser

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Satz, A. J. St. Louis, MO, A letter from A. J. Satz to isaac Leeser, asking for a detailed list of subscribers so that he can collect
Description 2: A letter from A. J. Satz to isaac Leeser, asking for a detailed list of subscribers so that he can collect

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Schwarz, Joseph. New York, NY, This four page document is Leeser's translation of a letter in German he had received from Rabbi Joseph Schwarz in New York. In this letter, Schwarz, the leading Jewish authority of Palestinian matters at the time,writes a general appeal, formally soliciting an annual pledge of funds from synagogues for needs in Palestine
Description 2: This four page document is Leeser's translation of a letter in German he had received from Rabbi Joseph Schwarz in New York. In this letter, Schwarz, the leading Jewish authority of Palestinian matters at the time,writes a general appeal, formally soliciting an annual pledge of funds from synagogues for needs in Palestine

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Seeligson, Michael. Galveston, TX, A letter written by Michael Seeligson (1797-1867) of Galveston, Texas, to Isaac Leeser, telling of his recent election as mayor of Galveston, Texas
Description 2: A letter written by Michael Seeligson (1797-1867) of Galveston, Texas, to Isaac Leeser, telling of his recent election as mayor of Galveston, Texas

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Seeligson, Michael. Galveston, TX, A letter written by Michael Seeligson, the first Jewish mayor of Galveston, Texas, to Isaac Leeser. In this letter, he writes of the consecration of a Hebrew cemetary in Galveston
Description 2: A letter written by Michael Seeligson, the first Jewish mayor of Galveston, Texas, to Isaac Leeser. In this letter, he writes of the consecration of a Hebrew cemetary in Galveston

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Seiling. Lancaster, PA, A letter from G. and J. Seiling Co. in Lancaster, Pennsylvania to Isaac Leeser, seeking the contract to paint his new synagogue, Beth El Emeth. They offer their credentials, experience, and enthusiasm for the job
Description 2: A letter from G. and J. Seiling Co. in Lancaster, Pennsylvania to Isaac Leeser, seeking the contract to paint his new synagogue, Beth El Emeth. They offer their credentials, experience, and enthusiasm for the job

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Seimehoff, E. Reading, PA, A letter from E. Selmehoff, secretary of Obef Scholem, to Isaac Leeser, asking him to discontinue their ad for a teacher, as they have now secured one
Description 2: A letter from E. Selmehoff, secretary of Obef Scholem, to Isaac Leeser, asking him to discontinue their ad for a teacher, as they have now secured one

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Seligman, Jacob. New York, NY, A letter from Jacob Seligman, the librarian of the Hebrew Young Mens Literary Association, to Isaac Leeser regarding a subscription
Description 2: A letter from Jacob Seligman, the librarian of the Hebrew Young Mens Literary Association, to Isaac Leeser regarding a subscription

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Shway, Henry. Alexandria, VA, A letter from Henry Shway, the first secretary of the Beth El Hebrew congregation in Alexandria, Virginia, to Isaac Leeser, asking Leeser to note in his paper the formation of a congregation for the holidays
Description 2: A letter from Henry Shway, the first secretary of the Beth El Hebrew congregation in Alexandria, Virginia, to Isaac Leeser, asking Leeser to note in his paper the formation of a congregation for the holidays

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Simmons, M. B. St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. He writes of the difficulties in getting issues of the Occident, and notes that Mr. Carillon is again minister and that Reform changes have been made. He then describes a dream of meeting Leeser, but then being awakened by an earth quake
Description 2: A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. He writes of the difficulties in getting issues of the Occident, and notes that Mr. Carillon is again minister and that Reform changes have been made. He then describes a dream of meeting Leeser, but then being awakened by an earth quake

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Simmons, M. B. St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser, informing him that he has just lost his young wife to consumption. He then brings Leeser up to date on the Jewish institutional difficulties onSt. Thomas, including the firing of the hazan, Mr. Carrillon. He concludes with book and newspaper matters
Description 2: A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser, informing him that he has just lost his young wife to consumption. He then brings Leeser up to date on the Jewish institutional difficulties onSt. Thomas, including the firing of the hazan, Mr. Carrillon. He concludes with book and newspaper matters

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Simmons, W. B. St. Thomas, West Indies, A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. He discusses writing James Henry in New York City for four cases of matzos and two sets of themurim. Additionally, he discusses selling Leeser's books
Description 2: A letter from M.B. Simmons of St. Thomas to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia. He discusses writing James Henry in New York City for four cases of matzos and two sets of themurim. Additionally, he discusses selling Leeser's books

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Slutsky, Louis. Buffalo, NY, A letter from Louis Slutsky in Buffalo, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, informing him that he can do translations and is looking for a job
Description 2: A letter from Louis Slutsky in Buffalo, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, informing him that he can do translations and is looking for a job

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Soher, Solomon. Shougalo, MS, A letter from Solomon Soher in Shougalo, Mississippi to Isaac Leeser. Soher writes to turn down Leeser's request for a loan
Description 2: A letter from Solomon Soher in Shougalo, Mississippi to Isaac Leeser. Soher writes to turn down Leeser's request for a loan

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Sollas, M. M. Jamacia, West Indies, A letter from Moses Mendes Sollas, a wealthy merchant, lay leader, and benefactor of K. K. Shahar Ashamaim in Kingston, Jamaica, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, he asks for information on a firm that can put up "spiced beef" for export to Jamaica. In addition, he gives his thoughts and advice to Leeser on his attempt to organize the broader jewish community in America. The last part includes book orders with names
Description 2: A letter from Moses Mendes Sollas, a wealthy merchant, lay leader, and benefactor of K. K. Shahar Ashamaim in Kingston, Jamaica, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, he asks for information on a firm that can put up "spiced beef" for export to Jamaica. In addition, he gives his thoughts and advice to Leeser on his attempt to organize the broader jewish community in America. The last part includes book orders with names

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Sollas, W. M. Kingston, Jamacia, A letter from Moses Mendes Sollas, a wealthy merchant, lay leader, and benefactor of K. K. Shahar Ashamaim in Kingston, Jamaica, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Sollas thanks Leeser for being his spiritual teacher, since, being old men, he doubts they will ever meet again
Description 2: A letter from Moses Mendes Sollas, a wealthy merchant, lay leader, and benefactor of K. K. Shahar Ashamaim in Kingston, Jamaica, to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Spanier, Louis. Albany, NY, A letter written by Louis Spanier of Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Spanier rails against Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise and calls for his public censure. The letter is written in German with an English translation
Description 2: A letter written by Louis Spanier of Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter, Spanier rails against Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise and calls for his public censure. The letter is written in German with an English translation

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Stein, D. Wheeling, WV, A letter from D. Stein in Wheeling, WV to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA. In this letter, he suggests that Leeser write to severl local Jews who refuse to accept his bible because they deny having subscribed. Also enclosed is a copy of the meeting of the Israelites of Wheeling
Description 2: A letter from D. Stein in Wheeling, WV to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA. In this letter, he suggests that Leeser write to severl local Jews who refuse to accept his bible because they deny having subscribed. Also enclosed is a copy of the meeting of the Israelites of Wheeling

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Stein, Daniel. Wheeling, WV, A letter from Daniel Stein in Wheeling, WV to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA. In this letter, Stein describes the Jewish activities in Wheeling, and tells of the election of Joel Eppinger as schochet, hazan, and teacher
Description 2: A letter from Daniel Stein in Wheeling, WV to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA. In this letter, Stein describes the Jewish activities in Wheeling, and tells of the election of Joel Eppinger as schochet, hazan, and teacher

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Strouse, Isaac. Pittsburgh, PA, A letter from Isaac Strouse of Pittsburgh, PA to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA, asking to be informed of what he owes Leeser for the past three years of subscription. This letter provides a rare chronicle of the devastating Pittsburgh fire of 1845
Description 2: A letter from Isaac Strouse of Pittsburgh, PA to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA, asking to be informed of what he owes Leeser for the past three years of subscription. This letter provides a rare chronicle of the devastating Pittsburgh fire of 1845

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Strouse, Isaac. Wilkes Barre, PA, A letter from Isaac Strouse in Wilkes Barre, PA to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA, describing the book he has written, a translation and interpretation of D. Ottensoser's work on Josephus, and why he considers it important. He asks if Leeser will review it and give his opinion, as well as mention it in the Occident
Description 2: A letter from Isaac Strouse in Wilkes Barre, PA to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, PA, describing the book he has written, a translation and interpretation of D. Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Strouse, Morris W. Wilkes Barre, PA, A signed letter from M. W. Strouse to Isaac Leeser, outlining the resolutions of the new congregation in Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania. He continues with a request for prayer books to be sold at a commission
Description 2: A signed letter from M. W. Strouse to Isaac Leeser, outlining the resolutions of the new congregation in Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania. He continues with a request for prayer books to be sold at a commission

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Tobais, Sophia. New York, NY, A note from Sophia Tobais in New York to Isaac Leeser, sending a report of the Ladies' Sewing Association, asking that it be published in the Occident
Description 2: A note from Sophia Tobais in New York to Isaac Leeser, sending a report of the Ladies' Sewing Association, asking that it be published in the Occident

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Tyler, Jas. P. Richmond, VA, A letter from Jas. P. Tyler of Richmond, Virginia to a young Isaac Leeser, informing him that he has given a letter of introduction to his friend Alexander Campell, and requesting that Leeser meet with him and his "sprightly single daughter"
Description 2: A letter from Jas. P. Tyler of Richmond, Virginia to a young Isaac Leeser, informing him that he has given a letter of introduction to his friend Alexander Campell, and requesting that Leeser meet with him and his "sprightly single daughter"

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Ullmann, Louis L. Cincinnati, OH, A letter from Louis L. Ullmann in Cinncinati, Ohio to Isaac Leeser. The letter is mostly in German
Description 2: A letter from Louis L. Ullmann in Cinncinati, Ohio to Isaac Leeser. The letter is mostly in German

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Valentine, S. Charleston, SC, A letter from S. Valentine to Rev. Isaac Leeser, forwarding a preamble and resolutions. It also includes a personal note that he will see him soon and that his family wishes to be remembered
Description 2: A letter from S. Valentine to Rev. Isaac Leeser, forwarding a preamble and resolutions. It also includes a personal note that he will see him soon and that his family wishes to be remembered

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Valentine, S. Charleston, SC, A letter from S. Valentine, the secretary of Shearith Israel, in Charleston, South Carolina to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania . Description 2: A letter from S. Valentine, the secretary of Shearith Israel, in Charleston, South Carolina to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania . The letter relates the religious conflict among the Jews of the city and complains that the Orthodox are being ridiculed

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Waterman, Sigismond. New York, NY, A letter from Dr. Sigismond Waterman, the first Jewish medical graduate from Princeton, to Isaac Leeser, criticizing Leeser for his personal attack and for how poorly he reacts to debate
Description 2: A letter from Dr. Sigismond Waterman, the first Jewish medical graduate from Princeton, to Isaac Leeser, criticizing Leeser for his personal attack and for how poorly he reacts to debate

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Weil, Solomon. New York, NY, A signed letter from Solomon Weil in New York to Isaac Leeser, sending $2.00 for his Occident and requesting previous issues. He also asks Leeser to insert notice in the next issue of his marriage
Description 2: A signed letter from Solomon Weil in New York to Isaac Leeser, sending $2.00 for his Occident and requesting previous issues. He also asks Leeser to insert notice in the next issue of his marriage

Description 2: Letter to Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia from Leopold Weiskopf in Charleston, South Carolina, in regard to a bill for subscription he did not believe he owed

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Wellen. San Francisco, CA, A gold rush era letter from Mr. Wellen, the postmaster in San Francisco to Isaac Leeser, informing him that eight Occidents were not picked up by Leeser's subscribers
Description 2: A gold rush era letter from Mr. Wellen, the postmaster in San Francisco to Isaac Leeser, informing him that eight Occidents were not picked up by Leeser's subscribers

Description 2: A letter from Rabbi Isaac Wise of Albany, New York to Rev. Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Written early in Wise's career, this letter hints at Rabbi Wise's strongly held opinions

Description 2: A note from Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise in Albany, New York to Rv. Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It deals with the ordering of 24 books

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A signed letter from from Isaac Mayer Wise to Isaac Leeser, explaining why he cannot collect any money for the Occident
Description 2: A signed letter from from Isaac Mayer Wise to Isaac Leeser, explaining why he cannot collect any money for the Occident

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A two and a half page letter from Isaac Wise in Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter contains a detailed attack on a previous article in the Occident by a person signed "Truth". Wise accuses the man of thinking in the narrow frame of a Chassid. Wise asks that his letter be published
Description 2: A two and a half page letter from Isaac Wise in Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter contains a detailed attack on a previous article in the Occident by a person signed "Truth". Wise accuses the man of thinking in the narrow frame of a Chassid. Wise asks that his letter be published

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A two and a half page letter from Isaac Wise in Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.This is the most important letter on the firsthand account of the "Congregation Beth-El of Albany Affair". (In 1850, a fistfight between Wise and the synagogue's president caused a split in the Albany community, and the consequent formation of a new congregation, the Anshe Emeth). Here Rabbi Isaac Wise writes in detail of the arguments at the Beth-El meeting in which he was discharged as Rabbi for leading the congregation toward a more liberal path. The letter mentions that a fight broke out, and the sheriff was called and he locked the building. Rabbi Isaac Wise identifies Louis Spanier as the instigator of the whole affair
Description 2: A two and a half page letter from Isaac Wise in Albany, New York to Isaac Leeser in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.This is the most important letter on the firsthand account of the "Congregation Beth-El of Albany Affair". (In 1850, a fistfight between Wise and the synagogue's president caused a split in the Albany community, and the consequent formation of a new congregation, the Anshe Emeth). Here Rabbi Isaac Wise writes in detail of the arguments at the Beth-El meeting in which he was discharged as Rabbi for leading the congregation toward a more liberal path. The letter mentions that a fight broke out, and the sheriff was called and he locked the building. Rabbi Isaac Wise identifies Louis Spanier as the instigator of the whole affair

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A two page letter from Rabbi Isaac Wise of Albany, New York to Rev. Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter deals with the "Congregation Beth-El of Albany Affair," when Rabbi Isaac Wise was physically attacked on the bimah and a fight broke out. In this letter Rev. Wise outlines his seven point legal citory against Louis Spanier, who tried to remove Wise from Beth El
Description 2: A two page letter from Rabbi Isaac Wise of Albany, New York to Rev. Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The letter deals with the "Congregation Beth-El of Albany Affair," when Rabbi Isaac Wise was physically attacked on the bimah and a fight broke out. In this letter Rev. Wise outlines his seven point legal citory against Louis Spanier, who tried to remove Wise from Beth El

Description 1: Leeser, Isaac and Wise, Isaac Mayer. Albany, NY, A two page letter from Rabbi Isaac Wise of Albany, New York to Rev. Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. In this letter one day after the fist fight, Rabbi Wise requests that Leeser publish an announcement about his ill treatment
Description 2: A two page letter from Rabbi Isaac Wise of Albany, New York to Rev. Isaac Leeser of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Description 1: Levy, Jacob Franks. Baltimore, MD, A letter from Jacob Franks Levy, son of Benjamin Levy, to William Augustine Washington (1757-1810), nephew of George Washington, in Westmoreland County, Virginia. Additionally, he asks if Washington still has shares in the "Potomak Canal," as he has a buyer

Description 1: Mordecai, Sarah Ann and Mordecai, Laura. Washington, DC, A letter written by Sarah Ann Mordecai in Washington D.C. to her daughter Laura Mordecai in Philadelphia. The letter describes, among other things, a rare visit by the First Lady, Jane Appleton Pierce, as well as Sarah's clear commitment to Judaism. Sarah's aunt was Rebecca Gratz through her mother Richea Gratz Hays. Sarah is married to Major Alfred Mordecai the renowned expert in artillery
Description 2: A letter written by Sarah Ann Mordecai in Washington D.C. to her daughter Laura Mordecai in Philadelphia. The letter describes, among other things, a rare visit by the First Lady, Jane Appleton Pierce, as well as Sarah's clear commitment to Judaism. New York, NY, These two documents provided insight into the personal lives of a well known Jewish artist and his wife, Jacob H. and Amelia B. nee' Tobias Lazarus, (1825-1906).
